results.title: The Silent one
results.creator_credit: Yvonne MacKay, David Gibson and Gibson Film Productions
results.brief_description: A deaf mute boy, Jonasi, the Silent One, arrives as a baby floating in from the sea to an isolated, paradisical Pacific village. He is adopted and raised by a childless woman. As a pubescent boy he is separated from the villagers and the coming-of-age rituals by his silence and their prejudices. In his isolation he seeks solace in the sea, with which he has always had a special, gifted bond. He developes a special relationship with a huge white turtle. Times are bad: the superstitious villagers blame both Jonasi and the turtle who are seen as evil spirits. A struggle for leadership sweeps Jonasi to his strange destiny. Starring Telo Malese (Jonasi), Pat Evison, Anzac Wallace, Rongo Tupatea Kahu. Spectacular underwater photography by Ron and Valerie Taylor. Based on the novel by Joy Gowley.

results.title: Watership down
results.brief_description:
One dim moonlit night, a small band of rabbits leave the comfort and safety of their warren and set out on a long and dangerous journey after a premonition of a terrible disaster that will overtake them if they stay. None of them knows where they are heading, or the dangers they will face in their search for a new warren where they can live in peace. Adapted from Richard Adams’ modern classic.
Voiced by actors including: John Hurt, Richard Briers, Ralph Richardson, Denholm Elliott, Zero Mostel, Nigel Hawthorne, Michael Hordern, Joss Ackland.

results.title: Pollyanna
results.brief_description: Adapted from the popular story by Eleanor Parker. Pollyanna (Hayley Mills) glows as the little orphan girl who believes that “things are always better than they seem”. She manages to change the heart of an entire town including her Aunt Polly (Jane Wyman). Judged by the public and critics alike as one of Walt Disney’s finest achievements. Pollyanna is a celebration of life. Rated G.

results.title: Babar's First Step
results.creator_credit: Clive A Smith, Michael Hirsh, Patricia Loubert and Raymond Jafelice
results.brief_description: Babar’s First Steps - Babar leads a happy and carefree life with his mother and all the other elephants in the jungle. But his life is shortened when a Hunter kills his mother and Babar must cope on his own. “City Ways” - Forced to run away from the jungle by the Hunter, Babar makes his way to the city, only to find it very dangerous and confusing. He is befriended by the Old Lady, who tries to teach him how to fit into her world. Rated: G

results.title: Life after death
results.brief_description: Brings into focus the question of the persistence of consciousness after biological death. Dr. Lawrence LeShan presents the scientific view. At a session at the Monroe Institute with Robert Monroe, author of “Journeys Out of the Body”, participants learn that they are more than their physical body. Dr. Kenneth Ring interviews four who were clinically dead. Margaret Flavell, a British medium, communicates with the late A. D. Mattson, who describes the hereafter.

results.title: Masters of Animation 2
results.brief_description: A survey of North American and French animation, both recent and past, including the work of the National Film Board of Canada and developments in computer animation. Rated: G

results.title: High and wild
results.creator_credit: David Greig and Kestrel Films & Video (Australia)
results.brief_description: High and Wild is the latest video from the Wilderness Society’s ongoing education program. It traces the journey of eight students and their teacher from Melbourne’s Kingswood College on what, for most, was their first wilderness experience. Shot on location in Victoria’s Wonnangatta-Moroka National Park “High and Wild” captures the students’ experience as they explore a variety of issues surrounding wilderness - such as alpine grazing logging, flora/fauna protection, outdoor recreation, Aboriginal and World Heritage values.

results.title: Towards 2000: Robots and Energy
results.brief_description: The Robots are Coming- More and more jobs are being taken over each year by the robots of the world. Most of the jobs are tedious, but the robots don’t seem to mind. “Energy”- The sun and the wind could supply us with most of our energy needs - pollution free. “Research Into Space”- The Americans and the Russians are showing the world that space has no boundaries but getting up there does present problems from time to time. “Other Changes”- Electronic bagpipes and a hotel room the size of a phone box - they are just two of the changes taking place right now.

results.title: The Living planet. - Part 1: the building of the earth
results.brief_description: Part One of a two part series. From the sub zero temperatures of the polar ice-caps to the baking heat of the deserts, from the ash-strewn sides of a volcano to the dense vegetation of a tropical forest, the environments on Earth are no less remarkable than the variety of life itself and almost nowhere on our planet is devoid of life. Narrated by David Attenborough.
